title: Latin Letters at the End of Antiquity
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: A linguistic and literary examination of texts that stand at the threshold of the Middle Ages across a variety of registers (vulgar, classicizing, biblical) and genres (theological, legal, hagiographic, epistolary) in order to understand the the forces that led to the development of the manifold varieties of Medieval Latin.

title: Latin Letters at the End of Antiquity
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: A linguistic and literary examination of texts that stand at the threshold of the Middle Ages across a variety of registers (vulgar, classicizing, biblical) and genres (theological, legal, hagiographic, epistolary) in order to understand the the forces that led to the development of the manifold varieties of Medieval Latin.

title: The Cambridge Songs
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Examines one of the most famous collections of Medieval Latin poetry. Considers the state of the manuscript, the formation of the collection, the interplay between secular and religious concerns, and the prosody.

title: The Cambridge Songs
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Examines one of the most famous collections of Medieval Latin poetry. Considers the state of the manuscript, the formation of the collection, the interplay between secular and religious concerns, and the prosody.

title: Latin Literature of the 10th and 11th Centuries
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the influence of the Benedictine reform movement in the 10th century as well as the rise of cathedral schools and court culture in the 11th century. Topics of special interest include the origins of dark styles; the relationship between hagiography and romance; and the interplay between Latin and vernacular literature. Readings include selections from Odo of Cluny, Liutprand of Cremona, the school of Aethelwold, Norman Latin poets, and the poets of the Loire Valley.

title: Latin Literature of the 10th and 11th Centuries
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the influence of the Benedictine reform movement in the 10th century as well as the rise of cathedral schools and court culture in the 11th century. Topics of special interest include the origins of dark styles; the relationship between hagiography and romance; and the interplay between Latin and vernacular literature. Readings include selections from Odo of Cluny, Liutprand of Cremona, the school of Aethelwold, Norman Latin poets, and the poets of the Loire Valley.

title: Wisdom and Learning
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Examines literature in which earthly wisdom and book learning are contrasted or conflated. Explores interaction among biblical, classical, and native (especially Germanic and Celtic) traditions of wisdom. Works include Solomon and Marcolf, mirrors for princes, proverbs, and question-and-answer dialogues. No prior experience with Medieval Latin necessary.

title: Latin Pastoral Poetry from Virgil to Milton
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: An examination of the Latin Pastoral tradition from Antiquity to the Renaissance and beyond. Emphasis will be placed on pastoral's generic status, its role in poetic self-fashioning, its relation to politics and Christianity, and intertextuality.

title: Pagan and Christian Poetry in Late Antiquity
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Close reading of a selection of authors from the 4th–6th century CE, including Ausonius, Paulinus of Nola, Juvencus, Proba, Claudian, and Boethius. We will explore authors' appropriation of classical literary forms, as well as innovations in genre (e.g. Biblical epic).

title: Abelard and Heloise
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Studies a 12th-century couple whose lives and writings left lasting marks on European culture. Besides selections from personal correspondence, examines parts of the Sic et non and Abelard's ethical writings, hymns, and lament poems. Close reading of Abelard's letters to correspondents other than Heloise. Considers reputation of Abelard and Heloise in later centuries. No prior experience with Medieval Latin necessary.

title: Abelard and Heloise
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Studies the 12th-century couple whose lives and writings left lasting marks on European culture. In addition to selections from their correspondence, examines parts of the Sic et Non and Abelard's ethical writings, representative hymns, and the Planctus. Close reading of Abelard's letters to correspondents other than Heloise. Intended for students of the Classics as well as for students of any aspect of the Middle Ages. Completion of Latin 4 or other preparation in Classical Latin satisfactory to the instructor.

title: Abelard and Heloise
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Studies a twelfth-century couple whose lives and writings left lasting marks on European culture. Besides selections from personal correspondence, examines parts of the Sic et non and Abelard's ethical writings, hymns, and lament poems. Close reading of Abelard's letters to correspondents other than Heloise. Considers reputation of Abelard and Heloise in later centuries. No prior experience with Medieval Latin necessary.

title: Virgil in the Middle Ages
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the reception of Virgil in the Middle Ages. Considers approaches taken to the Aeneid in particular in medieval education, from the most literal glosses and commentary in grammar schools to the allegorizations found in more advanced milieux. Surveys adaptations of Virgil's poems by vernacular poets (especially English, French, Italian, and German). Focuses also on folklore associated with Virgil and his poetry.

title: The Terentian Tradition
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: In this course, we will read a comedy of Terence (Eunuchus) and examine the literary conventions before moving on to later reworkings of Terentian comedy. Particular emphasis will be placed on the tenth-century abbess Rotsvita of Gandersheim (Dulcitius and Paphnutius) and her reimagining of the genre. How does she transform the classical comedy into a text of Christian edification? We will also pay attention to the intricate play with gender identity, as discussed in recent scholarship. For the final part of the course, we will take a quick look at humanist Christian reception of Terence (with selections from Gnapheus, Macropedius, and Schonaeus), and spend some time with Houghton's collection of Terentian manuscripts and incunables.

title: The Latin Bible: Seminar
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will explore the history and interpretation of the Latin translation(s) of the Christian Bible from the pre-Jerome Vetus Latina to the Clementine Vulgate. Portions from each of the major divisions of the Bible will be read in Latin and students will be introduced to some of the most important works of exegesis from Augustine's commentaries on the Psalms to the Glossa ordinaria and beyond. Students should have a strong reading knowledge of Latin, but no previous experience with Medieval Latin is required.

title: The Latin Bible: Seminar
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: This seminar will explore the history and interpretation of the Latin translation(s) of the Christian Bible from the pre-Jerome Vetus Latina to the Clementine Vulgate. Portions from each of the major divisions of the Bible will be read in Latin and students will be introduced to some of the most important works of exegesis from Augustine's commentaries on the Psalms to the Glossa ordinaria and beyond. Students should have a strong reading knowledge of Latin, but no previous experience with Medieval Latin is required.

title: Waltharius Seminar
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Studies a poem about an early Germanic hero, Walter of Aquitaine. Considers problems connected with the poem, from date and authorship to its essential meanings. Seeks to relate poem to both Germanic and Latin contexts, with attention to versions in other languages (in translation) and to sources and analogues in classical and Christian Latin literature.

title: Waltharius Seminar
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Studies a poem about an early Germanic hero, Walter of Aquitaine. Considers problems connected with the poem, from date and authorship to its essential meanings. Seeks to relate poem to both Germanic and Latin contexts, with attention to versions in other languages (in translation) and to sources and analogues in classical and Christian Latin literature.

title: Waltharius Seminar
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Studies a poem about an early Germanic hero, Walter of Aquitaine. Considers problems connected with the poem, from date and authorship to its essential meanings. Seeks to relate poem to both Germanic and Latin contexts, with attention to versions in other languages (in translation) and to sources and analogues in classical and Christian Latin literature.

title: Waltharius
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Beowulf was not the only Germanic heroic epic. Considers the Walter of Aquitaine poem, from authorship and date of composition to conflicting interpretations. Relates the text to both historical and literary (vernacular and Latin) contexts. Considers other versions of the legend, sources in classical and Christian Latin literature, and cultural reception from 1780 on.

title: Latin Biblical Epic
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: An exploration of the major Latin biblical epics. We will seek to place the epics in their literary, historical, and religious contexts. The poems will be approached from a variety of critical perspectives: as a reading of classical epic; the rhetorical paraphrase; didactic poetry and the poetry of edification, and so forth.

title: Latin Biblical Epic
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: An exploration of the major Latin biblical epics. We will seek to place the epics in their literary, historical, and religious contexts. The poems will be approached from a variety of critical perspectives: as a reading of classical epic; the rhetorical paraphrase; didactic poetry and the poetry of edification, and so forth.

title: Medieval Latin Encounters of Christianity and Islam
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: How did medieval Christians writing in Latin perceive Islam and its adherents? What knowledge did they possess, and how did they acquire it? How did they engage with Islam in various Latin literary forms, and to what end? These questions and many others will be at the center of this graduate seminar, in which students will read large amounts of medieval Latin prose and poetry spanning from the ninth to the fifteenth centuries in a variety of genres, from epic poetry to polemical treatise, including texts that were pivotal in shaping the perception of Islam in the Early Modern period and beyond. Designed for graduate students with a solid background in Latin (familiarity with medieval Latin not required), this seminar will allow students to develop a thorough knowledge of a topic that remains relevant to this day.

title: Alan of Lille: Seminar
subject: MEDLATIN
courseDescriptionLong: Among the most important intellectual figures of the Twelfth-Century Renaissance, Alan (ca. 1128-1203) earned the reputation of being doctor universalis. Seminar examines his life and works, including the allegories De planctu Naturae and Anticlaudianus and their reception, sermons, Bible dictionary, theology, and polemic writings.

title: Alan of Lille: Seminar

courseDescriptionLong: Among the most important intellectual figures of the Twelfth-Century Renaissance, Alan (ca. 1128-1203) earned the reputation of being doctor universalis. title: Introduction to Modern Greek Texts
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: This course is designed for students who possess an intermediate level in Modern Greek. It aims at further development of reading and listening comprehension as well as oral and written expression. The students will expand their vocabulary in thematic areas, such as technology, arts, environment, education, and politics. The course will also offer a targeted review of advanced grammatical phenomena, such as passive voice, indirect speech, and subordinate clauses. At the same time, the students will delve deeper into Modern Greek culture by being exposed to various cultural media, including prose (literary and journalistic), film, and music.

title: Advanced Modern Greek: Introduction to Modern Greek Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Special Topic: Narratives of the Greek Crisis: Prose, Cinema, and Performance. This course examines a variety of textual and visual narratives dealing with the Greek crisis. How is the "world's most messed up country" reflected in Greek literature, cinema, and theatre? How are the repercussions of the multifaceted crisis perceived by renowned and emerging authors and artists, both in Greece and abroad? What new literary genres have emerged out of this crisis? These are some of the questions that will be addressed in this course, while students are expected to enhance significantly their critical reading and writing skills.

title: Advanced Modern Greek: Introduction to Modern Greek Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Special Topic: Narratives of the Greek Crisis: Prose, Cinema, and Performance. This course examines a variety of textual and visual narratives dealing with the Greek crisis. How is the "world's most messed up country" reflected in Greek literature, cinema, and theatre? How are the repercussions of the multifaceted crisis perceived by renowned and emerging authors and artists, both in Greece and abroad? What new literary genres have emerged out of this crisis? These are some of the questions that will be addressed in this course, while students are expected to enhance significantly their critical reading and writing skills.

title: Advanced Modern Greek: Introduction to Modern Greek Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Special Topic: From Book to Film: Cinematic Representations of Modern Greek Literature. How do words translate into images? Can the interpretively fraught perspective of an author lend itself to the sensorily rife gaze of a director? Is it possible for an enthralling book to evolve into an equally astounding film? These are some of the questions that will be addressed in this course, as students gain knowledge about significant events in Modern Greek history that have long preoccupied and inspired acclaimed authors and distinguished filmmakers alike. Through engagement in narrative analysis and interpretation students will also be encouraged to whet their critical reading and writing skills. Authors include: Ioanna Karystiane, Nikos Kazantzakes, Strates Myriveles, Alexandros Papadiamantes, Kosmas Polites, Giorgos Skampardones, Dido Soteriou, Kostas Tachtses, and Georgios Vizyenos. Directors include, among others: Jules Dassin, Michales Kakoyannes, Kostas Koutsomytes, and Panteles Voulgares.

subject: MODGRK

title: Advanced Modern Greek: Introduction to Modern Greek Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Literary, sociocultural, and linguistic analysis of selected readings in prose, poetry, plays, orally transmitted songs, and folktales. Conducted in Greek. Modern Greek B or equivalent and permission of instructor.

title: Advanced Modern Greek: Introduction to Modern Greek Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Literary, sociocultural, and linguistic analysis of selected readings in prose, poetry, orally transmitted songs and folktales. Conducted in Greek. Modern Greek B or equivalent and permission of instructor.

title: Advanced Modern Greek: Introduction to Modern Greek Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Close literary and linguistic analysis of selected readings in prose, theatre, poetry, and folksongs. Authors include: Cavafy, Seferis, Elytis, Axioti, Kambanelis, Tachtsis, Iordanidou. Conducted in Greek. Students must have completed Modern Greek B or equivalent and must have permission of the instructor.

subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Literary, sociocultural, and linguistic analysis of selected readings in prose, poetry, orally transmitted songs and folktales. Conducted in Greek. Modern Greek B or equivalent and permission of instructor.

title: Advanced Modern Greek: Introduction to Modern Greek Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Special Topic: Introduction to the Poetry of Nobel Laureate George Seferis. Literary, sociocultural, and linguistic analysis of selected readings in prose, poetry, and literary criticism by George Seferis. Emphasis will also be given to the reception of the Nobel laureate Greek poet. Students will achieve linguistic and cultural competency while grasping a complete portrait of the poet and diplomat George Seferis within a broader historic and sociopolitical context of 20th-century Greece. Conducted in Greek. Modern Greek B or equivalent and permission of instructor.

title: Introduction to Modern Greek Culture
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Introduces Greek as well as non-Greek speakers to debates over neo-Hellenic identity as represented in important works of modern Greek poetry, prose, film, and music. Mindful of the European Union of 1992, explores texts written since the formation of the Greek state that problematize the ways by which Greeks have conceived of themselves in relation to Europe, the East, ancient Greece, Byzantium, and Turkey. Poets include Cavafy, Seferis, Elytis; the prose of Roidis, Myrivilis, Kazantzakis, Tachisis, Karapanou, Spanidou also examined. Viewing of contemporary films by Angelopoulos, Voulgaris, Papatakis, and Gavras. All texts available in Greek and English. Discussion in English. Students of Greek language are expected to read in Greek and meet weekly with instructor for a supplementary one-hour Greek discussion.

title: Introduction to Modern Greek Culture
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Introduces Greek as well as non-Greek speakers to debates over neo-Hellenic identity as represented in important works of modern Greek poetry, prose, film, and music. Mindful of the European Union of 1992, explores texts written since the formation of the Greek state that problematize the ways by which Greeks have conceived of themselves in relation to Europe, the East, ancient Greece, Byzantium, and Turkey. Poets include Cavafy, Seferis, Elytis; the prose of Roidis, Myrivilis, Kazantzakis, Tachisis, Karapanou, Spanidou also examined. Viewing of contemporary films by Angelopoulos, Voulgaris, Papatakis, and Gavras. All texts available in Greek and English. Discussion in English. Students of Greek language are expected to read in Greek and meet weekly with instructor for a supplementary one-hour Greek discussion.

title: Greek and Black Women's Voices
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: A comparative approach to representations of women and to women writers in two very different cultures where women's storytelling traditions have helped shape in modern prose fiction a distinctive blend of fantasy and documentary, magic and realism, and where the dominant theme of violence within and around the family is often unfolded against the background of collective ^'choral' voices. Readings include Melpo Axioti, Evgenia Fakinou, Irene Spanidou, Kostas Tachtsis, Buchi Emecheta, Toni Morrison, Gloria Naylor, Alice Walker. All texts available in English, but graduates and undergraduate concentrators are assigned additional texts as relevant to their fields. Intended primarily for undergraduates and graduates in the Classics, Comparative Literature, Folklore and Mythology, Modern Greek, and Women's Studies.

title: Greek and Black Women's Voices
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: A comparative approach to women writers and representations of women in two cultures where women's oral traditions have helped shape a distinctive blend of documentary and fantasy in modern prose fiction. Readings include: Alexandros Papadiamandis, Stratis Myrivilis, Kostas Tachtsis, Melpo Axioti, Eva Vlami, Alki Zei, Irene Spanidou, Toni Morrison, Gloria Naylor, Alice Walker, and Audre Lorde. Greek texts available in translation.

title: Survey of Modern Greek Poetry in Translation (1823-1997)
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: An introductory selective survey and critical interpretation of Modern Greek poets: Solomos, Palamas, Cavafy, Sikelianos, Seferis, Elytis, Embirikos, Gatsos, Ritsos, Sachtouris, Sinopoulos, Anagnostakis, Anghelaki-Rooke, Christianopoulos. Systematic discussion will focus on the influences of the poetical tradition, prior to the 19th century, as well as on contemporary theoretical approaches. All texts available in English; graduates are assigned additional texts relevant to their fields.

title: Greece in the Eyes of the West, 1453-1995
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: An introductory selective survey and critical interpretation of Western conceptions of Greece and the Greeks in a variety of contexts_classicism, philohellenism, hellenophobia, etc. Readings from Sidney, Winckelmann, the British Romantics, French travelers, Arnold Durrell, DeLillo; Greek mainland and diaspora appropriations of and resistance to such images (Roidis, Cavafy, Seferis, the neo-Orthodox). Also viewing of Zorba the Greek, Never on Sunday, Shirley Valentine; Angelopoulos' Landscape in the Mist, and Damianos' Evdokia, as well as reading press samples from The Economist and The New York Times. All texts available in English; graduates are assigned additional texts as relevant to their fields.

title: Survey of Modern Greek Poetry in Translation (1823-1997)
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: An introductory selective survey and critical interpretation of Modern Greek poets: Solomos, Palamas, Cavafy, Sikelianos, Seferis, Elytis, Embirikos, Gatsos, Ritsos, Sachtouris, Sinopoulos, Anagnostakis, Anghelaki-Rooke, Christianopoulos. title: The Modern Modern Greek Novel
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: A close study of Greek prose fiction of the last thirty years and an analysis of the reasons that fiction has dethroned poetry as the most prominent genre in Greece. Authors include: Tachtsis, Douka, Matessis, Zatelli, Valtinos, Galanaki, Kranaki, Kotzias. The seminar will draw comparisons with celebrated works from "related" traditions that have achieved recognition in the West in order to define contexts from which such Greek novels could reach a broader Anglo-American audience. All texts available in English; graduates are assigned additional texts as relevant to their fields.

title: The Oral Tradition: Demotic Songs, Wonder Tales and Shadow Theater Plays
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: After an introduction on all three orally transmitted genres, theoretical material, like Lord, Bakhtin, Alexiou, Nagy, and Sifakis will be used for a closer look on the methods of composition and dissemination. A variety of themes - love, marriage, heroism, death - will serve as guides to our exploration of the similarities and dissimilarities occuring between the genres. Also, comparative material from other Eastern Mediterranean cultures is going to be studied. Readings available in English translation. Students in Greek will be expected to read the material in Greek.

title: The Oral Tradition: Demotic Songs, Wonder Tales and Shadow Theater Plays
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: After an introduction on all three orally transmitted genres, theoretical material, like Lord, Bakhtin, Alexiou, Nagy, and Sifakis will be used for a closer look on the methods of composition and dissemination. title: Modern Greek Theatre
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines Modern Greek theatre in its multiple aspects from its relation to Greek tragedy through the stage revival of ancient drama to its contemporary status. Through a variety of perspectives and methods, students will explore several seminal plays with a particular emphasis on contemporary playwrights and avant-garde stage directors. Course taught in English. No Final Exam.

title: Modern Greek Theatre
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: This course examines Modern Greek theatre in its multiple aspects from its relation to Greek tragedy through the stage revival of ancient drama to its contemporary status. Through a variety of perspectives and methods, students will explore several seminal plays with a particular emphasis on contemporary playwrights and avant-garde stage directors. Course taught in English. No Final Exam.

title: Modern Greek Theatre
subject: MODGRK

Course taught in English. No Final Exam.

title: Greek Cinema
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: This survey course examines Greek cinema in a broader historical, cultural and sociopolitical context. From its beginnings (the silent era) to the present, and through a variety of perspectives and methods, students will not only become acquainted with the major trends, figures, and works of Greek cinema, but they will also develop an understanding of the major historical events of Greece. Particular emphasis will be placed on the work of Theo Angelopoulos and the documentary genre, with such representatives as Maria Iliou, Phillipos Koutsaftis, and Vassilis Loules. Through the lenses of everyday personal stories, the documentaries will shed light on the turbulent history of Greece. Weekly screenings. Course taught in English. No prerequisites.

title: Cross-Cultural Writing Workshop in Greek
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: A workshop structured to provide the opportunity for students with knowledge of modern Greek to explore their own writing from a cross-cultural point of view. Emphasis placed on the bilingual understanding of a culture through narration, and on the question of women's writing. Modern Greek A and B or equivalent.

title: Cross-Cultural Writing Workshop in Greek
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: A workshop structured to provide the opportunity for students with knowledge of modern Greek to explore their own writing from a cross-cultural point of view. Emphasis placed on the bilingual understanding of a culture through narration, and on the question of women's writing. Modern Greek A and B or equivalent.

title: Between Myth and Fiction, East and West
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: A close reading of six stories by George Vizyenos (1849-96) against his dual heritage of Greek/Ottoman oral traditions and older literary-artistic modes of perception and representation. Vizyenos' use of ekphrasis and antithesis is studied alongside his intertextual play with the German Romantic appropriation of ancient Greece and his challenge to prevailing concepts of nation and gender, language and realism, rationalism and superstition.

title: Ritual and Metaphor in Greek Songs of the Life Cycle
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the interdependence of ritual and metaphor by relating the imagery of the songs to rituals traditionally performed, primarily by women, at each stage of the life cycle. Further examines how the same images may be creatively adapted to contexts of birth and death, love and marriage, forming a common but variable metaphorical system, in which the human and natural worlds are constantly juxtaposed. Studied in this way, love songs and lullabies can lend new dimensions of meaning to the laments sung for departure at marriage, exile, and death. Questions of gender and power, morality and religion, eroticism and sexuality, are discussed throughout the collections published since the early 19th century. Texts studied in Greek; but translations, vocabularies, and linguistic commentaries are available. Intended primarily for graduates and undergraduates in Greek, the Classics, Comparative Literature, and Anthropology, with additional assignments and tutorials for graduates who may wish to integrate this course more closely with their major field.

title: Images of Greece in Modern Visual Cultures
subject: MODGRK

title: Exploring Modernism: The Poetry of C.P. Cavafy and G. Seferis
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the ways in which Cavafy and Seferis responded to modernist aesthetics and constructed their personal poetic mythology. Topics to be studied include: tradition and modernism, nostalgia and memory, poetics and desire.

title: The Poetry of C. P. Cavafy
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Cavafy is regarded today as one of the major poets in the literary canon, Greek and European; but in what ways does his poetry resist closure, challenging from the margins of Europe prevailing attitudes to nation, gender, and language? In addition to close readings of the poems, a selection of critical and theoretical works is used to discuss wider issues, such as tradition and modernity, aestheticism and modernism, poetics and sexual orientation. All Cavafy's poems have been extensively translated, but some knowledge of Greek is an advantage. Intended primarily for graduates and undergraduates in Greek, the Classics, and Comparative Literature.

title: Greek Tales
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Constantly shifting shapes, Greek tales have proved remarkably versatile and resilient. Our primary focus will be on the tales (paramythia) recorded from most parts of the Greek-speaking world after the formation of the modern nation state (1830). Topics will include: generic diversity; narrative techniques; performative contexts; metamorphosis morality; cosmic reciprocity. We shall also explore modes of transmission; in particular, evidence for oral literary interactions in the past (medieval paraphraseis and metaphraseis), and creative uses of traditional tales in modern fiction. Where appropriate, comparisons will be made with European and other folktales. Suitable for undergraduates and graduates in Modern Greek, Classics, Comparative Literature, Anthropology, Folklore and Mythology. Knowledge of Greek expected; some texts available in translation.

title: Greek Tales
subject: MODGRK

title: Greek Folksongs: Poetry, Music, and Dance
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: An introduction to modern Greek traditional culture which persists vigorously to the present and continues to influence Greek writers and composers. Song texts from the islands and mainland studied within their social and historical contexts. Particular emphasis on the vocal, instrumental, and dance tradition. Illustrations from field recordings, slides, and film. Readings in Greek and in translation; assignments from the selective discography discussed in class; participation in class dancing expected at alternate lectures.

title: Greek Folklore: The Magic of the Wondertales
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Spinning tales and weaving pictures: the traditional craft of storytelling in Greece as a web of enduring images and narrative contingencies; enchantment and metamorphosis as means of exploring cyclical concepts of body and cosmos that transgress moral, aesthetic, and generic boundaries. Oral-literary and cross-cultural interaction renders the Greek tales particularly relevant to an understanding of the intersections of myth and metaphor, fiction and film. Tales recorded from the 1840s to the present day (available in translation) are studied from diverse theoretical perspectives and within their social and historical context. Some participation in tale performance (in English or Greek) is expected.

title: Greek Songs and Scottish Ballads
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: A comparative perspective on Greek and Scottish narrative songs collected and sung since the late 18th century, with particular emphasis on their relation to mythology and the ^'other world.' How do Greek songs play on paradox, and why do the Scottish ballads seem to be more tragic/romantic? Reference is made to the classic collections by Politis, Ioannou, Child, and others, while all texts are available in English. Also surveys the development of folklore studies in Europe and Greece. Intended primarily for undergraduates and graduates in Greek, the Classics, Folklore and Mythology, Anthropology.

title: Greek Songs and Scottish Ballads
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: A comparative perspective on Greek and Scottish narrative songs collected and sung since the late 18th century, with particular emphasis on their relation to mythology and the ^'other world.' How do Greek songs play on paradox, and why do the Scottish ballads seem to be more tragic/romantic? Reference is made to the classic collections by Politis, Ioannou, Child, and others, while all texts are available in English. Also surveys the development of folklore studies in Europe and Greece. Intended primarily for undergraduates and graduates in Greek, the Classics, Folklore and Mythology, Anthropology.

title: Greek Songs and European Ballads
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: A comparative approach to narrative songs, with particular on their relation to mythology and the other world. How are stories told in song? Why do Greek (and other Balkan) songs play on paradox and parody, whereas Scottish, English and other classic ballads seem more tragic/romantic? In what different ways has the ballad interacted with literary prose and poetry (select examples)? And what about the music? These and other questions will be explored, with reference to available archival materials as well as to the major collections. We shall also survey the development of folklore studies in relation to modern nation state formation. All texts are available in English; no prior knowledge of Greek (or musical expertise) will be assumed. Intended primarily for undergraduates and graduates in Anthropology, Folklore and Mythology, Classics, Comparative Literature, Literature Concentration. Celticists particularly welcome.

title: Laments
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: The lament as a ritual performance has virtually disappeared from modern civilization. The Greek-speaking world, with its living folk traditions and 3000-year-old recorded history, can help us to explore: the diverse forms of the genre, expressed primarily by women since time immemorial; the interactions between orality and literacy, ritual and poetry; and the dynamics for social protest. Sources will include literature (e.g. epic, tragedy, lyric), iconography, and musical performances (folk songs, field recordings), drawn diachronically from Greek and other cultures. Comparative and anthropological perspectives will be applied throughout. All materials will be available in English translation, although students will be encouraged to read in the originals where possible.

title: Ritual and Religious Dimensions in Modern Greek Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: An exploration of ritual performance, religious symbolism and imagery in Greek poetry and prose during the later nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Starting from folk songs and tales, we shall examine literary texts ranging from Solomos and Papadiamandis to Sikelianos, Varnalis, Elytis and Kazantzakis. We shall question theoretical assumptions on the secularization of literary texts, testing them against close and comparative readings. Knowledge of Modern Greek to 100 level an advantage. All texts available in translation.

title: Greeks and the Irrational
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Close readings of literary works centering on dreams, the fantastic, and other paralogic dimensions in Modern Greek literature.

title: Dreams and Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Against the dual background of ancient and medieval commentaries on the one hand, and modern psychoanalytic and ethnographic studies on the other, diverse literary texts will be explored. The major focus will be on modern Greek literature and oral culture, but examples from ancient and Byzantine literature will also be considered, alongside comparative examples from other literatures and cultures (including film). Major topics: typology of dreams; dreams as narratives; religious dimensions. Theoretical readings to include: Aristotle, Aelius Aristides, Artemidoros, Synesios; Freud, Jung, Levi-Strauss, Turner, Foucault, Lyotard. Key texts available in translation; graduate students to do extra readings in the original Greek.

title: Gender, Nation, and Language in Modern Greek Poetry
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Selected poems from the 20th century analyzed to discuss the interaction between concepts of gender, nation, and language and to explore the politics of canon formation. Some texts available in translation, but knowledge of modern Greek is advantageous.

title: Gender, Nation, and Language in Modern Greek Poetry
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Selected poems from the 20th century analyzed to discuss the interaction between concepts of gender, nation, and language and to explore the politics of canon formation. Some texts available in translation, but knowledge of modern Greek is advantageous.

title: C. P. Cavafy and J. Merrill
subject: MODGRK

title: Greek World Literature: From Homer to Kazantzakis, Cavafy, and Beyond
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: The course focuses on examples of Greek world literature that had a great influence on authors across geographical and linguistic boundaries. Works and authors to be discussed include the Homeric epics, ancient Greek tragedy, C. P. Cavafy, N. Kazantzakis, G. Seferis, O. Elytis, G. Ritsos.

title: Greek World Literature: From Homer to Kazantzakis, Cavafy, and Beyond
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: The course focuses on examples of Greek world literature that had a great influence on authors across geographical and linguistic boundaries. Works and authors to be discussed include the Homeric epics, ancient Greek tragedy, C. P. Cavafy, N. Kazantzakis, G. Seferis, O. Elytis, G. Ritsos.

title: Imagining the Ancients: The Classical Tradition in Modern Greek Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Ancient Greece has always exerted an ^'^'anxiety of influence'' on Modern Greek cultural and political life. Examples drawn mainly from Koraes, Papadiamantes, Palamas, Cavafy, Sikelianos, Seferis, Elytis will illustrate the ways in which the classical tradition has been manipulated in 19th and 20th century-Greek literature; parallels from other literatures and examples from folklore material (songs, traditions, folktales) will also be discussed. All texts will be available in English.

title: Imagining the Ancients: The Classical Tradition in Modern Greek Literature
subject: MODGRK

title: Greek Modernism
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the theory and practice of Greek Modernism and its response to European literary context, focusing on ``The Generation of the 1930s'' and the Surrealists. All texts available in English.

title: Greek Modernism
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the ways in which Greek literature contributed and responded to modernist aesthetics. Topics to be studied include tradition and modernity, nostalgia and memory, poetics and desire.

title: Greek Modernism
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on the ways in which Greek literature contributed and responded to modernist aesthetics. Topics to be studied include tradition and modernity, nostalgia and memory, poetics and desire.

title: The Nazis and the Greeks
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the reception of Greek culture in Nazi Germany and the cultural, historical, and political implications of the occupation of Greece by the Nazis.

title: Greece and the Balkans
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: The cultural crossroads of the Balkans encompass a variety of landscapes, peoples, and cultures. The main focus of this course will be the historical and cultural contextualization of Greece within the area. It offers a critical overview of the politics of historical continuity and the recent resurgence of Balkan nationalism.

title: Greece and the Balkans
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: The cultural crossroads of the Balkans encompass a variety of landscapes, peoples, and cultures. The main focus of this course will be the historical and cultural contextualization of Greece within the area. title: Dreams and Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Against the dual background of ancient and medieval commentaries on the one hand, and modern psychoanalytic and ethnographic studies on the other, diverse literary texts will be explored. The major focus will be on Greek literature, but examples from other European literatures will also be considered (including film). Major topics: typology of dreams; dreams as narratives; dreaming and writing; religious dimensions. Theoretical readings to include: Aristotle, Aelius Aristides, Artemidorus, Synesius of Cyrene; Freud, Jung, Levi-Strauss, Foucault, Lyotard. Movies by Bergman, Fellini, Kurosawa, Kubrick, Scorcese, Tarkovsky will be also discussed.

title: The Greek Novel: From Antiquity to Modernity
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the development of the genre of the novel from late antiquity to Greek postmodernism. Medieval Greek and modern Western European examples will also be explored.

title: The Greek Novel
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the development of the genre of the novel from late antiquity to Greek postmodernism. Medieval Greek and modern Western European examples will also be explored.

title: The Greek Novel

title: The Avant-Garde and Its "Margins"
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: This course explores the avant-garde's subversion of established aesthetic premises and of the very institution of art in different European contexts. Special emphasis is placed on Western European and Greek surrealism, its complex associations with Greek tradition (ancient and modern), and on its interaction with the newly founded disciplines of anthropology and psychoanalysis. All texts are available in English.

title: The Avant-Garde and Its "Margins"
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: This course explores the avant-garde's subversion of established aesthetic premises and of the very institution of art in different European contexts. Special emphasis is placed on Western European and Greek surrealism, its complex associations with Greek tradition (ancient and modern), and on its interaction with the newly founded disciplines of anthropology and psychoanalysis. All texts are available in English.

title: Modern Greek Prose Fiction: c. 1850-Present
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: A close study of select works aimed to suggest some recurrent and less usual perspectives on gender, language, and nation. Authors include: Emmanuel Roidis, Georgios Vizymenos, Alexandros Papadiamandis, Stratis Myrivilis, Nikos Kazantzakis, Dido Soteriou, Melpo Axioti, Maro Douka, Evgenia Fakinou, and Kostas Tachtsis. Comparative reference made to other world literatures: African-American (Tony Morrison) and English (Thomas Hardy). All major texts are available in English translation. Knowledge of modern Greek required for graduate students.

title: Modern Greek Prose Fiction: c. 1850-Present
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: A close study of select works aimed to suggest some recurrent and less usual perspectives on gender, language, and nation. Authors include: Emmanuel Roidis, Georgios Vizymenos, Alexandros Papadiamandis, Stratis Myrivilis, Nikos Kazantzakis, Dido Soteriou, Melpo Axioti, Maro Douka, Evgenia Fakinou, and Kostas Tachtsis. title: Modern Greek Literature: Open Forum
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Graduates in Modern Greek will present topics for debate and analysis, as appropriate to te current stage of their research. There is no fixed syllabus, but important questions will be addressed. Harvard and outside faculty will be invited to contribute to an ongoing debate on specific issues.

title: Exploring Modernism: The Poetry of C.P. Cavafy and G. Seferis
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the ways in which Cavafy and Seferis responded to modernist aesthetics and constructed their personal poetic mythology. Topics include: tradition and modernism, nostalgia and memory, poetics and desire.

title: Exploring Modernism: The Poetry of C.P. Cavafy and G. Seferis

title: Exploring Modernism: The Poetry of C.P. Cavafy and G. Seferis
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the ways in which Cavafy and Seferis responded to modernist aesthetics and constructed their personal poetic mythology. Topics include: tradition and modernism, nostalgia and memory, poetics and desire.

title: Approaches to Modern Greek Oral Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores different genres of modern Greek oral literature and their performative contexts. Examines the interaction between orality and literacy, ritual and ``text,'' metaphor and performance. Comparative examples and original material recorded by the instructor will be also studied. All texts available in English. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Exploring Modernism: The Poetry of C.P. Cavafy and G. Seferis
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the ways in which Cavafy and Seferis responded to modernist aesthetics and constructed their personal poetic mythology. Topics include: tradition and modernism, nostalgia and memory, poetics and desire. All texts available in English. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Poetics of the Spirit: Nikos Kazantzakis
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Examines Kazantzakis's work in juxtaposition with European aestheticism and the philosophy of Nietzsche and Berxon. Topics include: love and sacrifice, salvation and death, transcendence and tragedy. Films based on his novels are also discussed. All texts available in English although students will be encouraged to read in the original when possible. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: The Modern Novel
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Starting from late antiquity, we shall study Greek novelistic genres to illuminate how their diverse forms and functions have contributed to the making of the modern novel, and may continue to shape present directions. Recurring themes, such as sex and violence, crime and punishment, love and marriage, will be considered in the context of changing social and religious structures. Particular attention will be paid to dreams, imagery, and ekphrasis as modes of representation. Comparative examples will be drawn from modern European and African-Amercian literatures. Most texts will be available in English translation, but students of Greek will be expected to read as much as possible in the original. In Fall 1999, Greek Perspectives on the Modern Novel will continue with a study of oral traditional tales.

title: The Modern Novel
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Starting from late antiquity, we shall study Greek novelistic genres to illuminate how their diverse forms and functions have contributed to the making of the modern novel, and may continue to shape present directions. Recurring themes, such as sex and violence, crime and punishment, love and marriage, will be considered in the context of changing social and religious structures. Particular attention will be paid to dreams, imagery, and ekphrasis as modes of representation. Comparative examples will be drawn from modern European and African-Amercian literatures. Most texts will be available in English translation, but students of Greek will be expected to read as much as possible in the original. In Fall 1999, Greek Perspectives on the Modern Novel will continue with a study of oral traditional tales.

title: Imagining the Ancients: The Classical Tradition in Modern Greek Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the ways in which classical tradition has been manipulated in 19th and 20th century Greek literature and has contributed to the formation of modern Greek literary canon.

title: Imagining the Ancients: The Classical Tradition in Modern Greek Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the ways in which classical tradition has been manipulated in 19th and 20th century Greek literature and has contributed to the formation of modern Greek literary canon.

title: Imagining the Ancients: The Classical Tradition in Modern Greek Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the ways in which classical tradition has been manipulated in 19th and 20th century Greek literature and has contributed to the formation of modern Greek literary canon.

title: The Novel
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: The Greek novel from late antiquity to modern Greek literature. Special emphasis is given to ancient Greek and Byzantine examples of the genre. Particular attention is paid to rhetorical modes of representation (ekphrasis, syncrisis, encomium, ethopoiia). Most texts available in translation, but students of Greek will be expected to read as much as possible in the original. Students will beable to work on comparative/additional texts according to their researchinterests.

title: The Modern Novel
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Starting from late antiquity, we shall study Greek novelistic genres to illuminate how their diverse forms and functions have contributed to the making of the modern novel, and may continue to shape present directions. Recurring themes, such as sex and violence, crime and punishment, love and marriage, will be considered in the context of changing social and religious structures. Particular attention will be paid to dreams, imagery, and ekphrasis as modes of representation. Comparative examples will be drawn from modern European and African-Amercian literatures. Most texts will be available in English translation, but students of Greek will be expected to read as much as possible in the original. In Fall 1999, Greek Perspectives on the Modern Novel will continue with a study of oral traditional tales.

title: Poetics of the Spirit: Nikos Kazantzakis
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Examines Kazantzakis's work in juxtaposition with European aestheticism and the philosophy of Nietzsche and Berxon. Topics include: love and sacrifice, salvation and death, transcendence and tragedy. Films based on his novels are also discussed. All texts available in English although students will be encouraged to read in the original when possible. Open to qualified undergraduates.

title: Modern Greek Oral Literature: Interdisciplinary and Comparative Perspectives
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the interaction of orality and literacy in premodern Greek societies, with an emphasis on the performative and ritual contexts of oral traditional literature. Ethnographic examples from other cultures will also be discussed.

title: Theodore Prodromos, Four Begging Poems
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: The poet adopts in turn a different persona in his appeals to Manuel I Komnenos and others for money: henpecked husband, impecurious paterfamilias, abused monk, starving scholar. Humor satire and erudition are skillfully combined in these vernacular vignettes of everyday life in 12th-century Constantinople. Suitable for Byzantinists, new-hellinists, and classicists, with topics to be selected in accordance with particular research requirements. Knowledge of Greek.

title: Modern Greek Oral Literature: Interdisciplinary and Comparative Perspectives
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the interaction of orality and literacy in premodern Greek societies, with an emphasis on the performative and ritual contexts of oral traditional literature. Ethnographic examples from other cultures will also be discussed.

title: Theodore Prodromos, Four Begging Poems
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: The poet adopts in turn a different persona in his appeals to Manuel I Komnenos and others for money: henpecked husband, impecurious paterfamilias, abused monk, starving scholar. Humor satire and erudition are skillfully combined in these vernacular vignettes of everyday life in 12th-century Constantinople. Suitable for Byzantinists, new-hellinists, and classicists, with topics to be selected in accordance with particular research requirements. Knowledge of Greek.

title: The Historical Novel
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Against a background of theoretical readings on historiography, the historical novel, historiographic metafiction, and generic criticism, major examples of the Greek historical novel and their dialogue with broader cultural and political issues will be explored. Authors studied include: Rangavis, Papadiamantis, Karagatsis, Terzakis, Vlachos,Valtinos, Galanaki, Douka.

title: The Historical Novel
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Against a background of theoretical readings on historiography, the historical novel, historiographic metafiction, and generic criticism, major examples of the Greek historical novel and their dialogue with broader cultural and political issues will be explored. Authors studied include: Rangavis, Papadiamantis, Karagatsis, Terzakis, Vlachos,Valtinos, Galanaki, Douka.

title: The Historical Novel
subject: MODGRK

Authors studied include: Rangavis, Papadiamantis, Karagatsis, Terzakis, Vlachos,Valtinos, Galanaki, Douka.

title: Satire and Parody in the Greek Tradition from Lucian to Skatablattas
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Studies the variety of satirical and comic modes in Greek literature (Lucianic dialogue, parody, diatribe, satirical fiction) and their development from Late Antiquity to Late Byzantium. Qualified undergraduates welcome; knowledge of Greek, while desirable, is not a prerequisite.

title: Satire and Parody in the Greek Tradition from Lucian to Skatablattas
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Studies the variety of satirical and comic modes in Greek literature (Lucianic dialogue, parody, diatribe, satirical fiction) and their development from Late Antiquity to Late Byzantium. title: Satire and Parody in the Greek Tradition from Lucian to Skatablattas
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Studies the variety of satirical and comic modes in Greek literature (Lucianic dialogue, parody, diatribe, satirical fiction) and their development from Late Antiquity to Late Byzantium. Qualified undergraduates welcome; knowledge of Greek, while desirable, is not a prerequisite.

title: C.P. Cavafy: European Modernism and the Poetics of Desire
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Studies the development of Cavafy's poetics and its connections with the broader sociocultural context of European aestheticism and modernism. Focuses on the articulation of desire and on current debates in gender studies and psychoanalytic theory.

title: C.P. Cavafy: European Modernism and the Poetics of Desire
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Studies the development of Cavafy's poetics and its connections with the broader sociocultural context of European aestheticism and modernism. Focuses on the articulation of desire and on current debates in gender studies and psychoanalytic theory.

title: C.P. Cavafy: European Modernism and the Poetics of Desire
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Studies the development of Cavafy's poetics and its connections with the broader sociocultural context of European aestheticism and modernism. Focuses on the articulation of desire and on current debates in gender studies and psychoanalytic theory.

title: C.P. Cavafy: European Modernism and the Poetics of Desire
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Studies the development of Cavafy's poetics and its connections with the broader sociocultural context of European aestheticism and modernism. Focuses on the articulation of desire and on current debates in gender studies and psychoanalytic theory.

title: Reception as Cultural Politics: Classical Tradition in Modern Greek Contexts
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the complex ways in which ancient Greek socio-aesthetic cultures are reconstructed and reworked in 19th- and 20th-century Greek and other European traditions, with special emphasis on Greek modernism, avant-garde, and post-modernism.

title: Politics of Reception: Classical Antiquity in Modern Critical Theory and Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the formation of classics as a discipline in the post-Enlightenment era and the ways in which antiquity and its study informed major manifestations of modern theoretical, philosophical, and literary discourses. All texts are available in English.

title: Politics of Reception: Classical Antiquity in Modern Critical Theory and Literature
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the formation of classics as a discipline in the post-Enlightenment era and the ways in which antiquity and its study informed major manifestations of modern theoretical, philosophical, and literary discourses. All texts are available in English.

title: Reception as Cultural Politics: Classical Tradition in Modern Greek Contexts
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the complex ways in which ancient Greek socio-aesthetic cultures are reconstructed and reworked in 19th- and 20th-century Greek and other European traditions, with special emphasis on Greek modernism, avant-garde, and post-modernism.

title: Topics in Modern Greek Studies
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Focuses on current debates on theoretical and methodological issues in the field. Topics to be discussed include: diaspora, reception, postcolonialism, cultural politics, translation.

title: Greek Imaginaries
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores theoretical discussions and literary exemplifications of the concepts of "phantasia," fictionality, the marvelous, and the real in Greek contexts, with a special focus on early modern Greek literature and thought.

title: Greek Imaginaries
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores theoretical discussions and literary exemplifications of the concepts of "phantasia," fictionality, the marvelous, and the real in Greek contexts, with a special focus on early modern Greek literature and thought.

title: The Poetics of Eros: From Plato to C. P. Cavafy
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores postclassical Greek and broader European literary receptions of Plato's theory of eros. Special emphasis is placed on the rediscovery of "Hellenic love" in British aestheticism and Greek modernism, especially in C. P. Cavafy.

title: The Poetics of Eros: From Plato to C. P. Cavafy
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores postclassical Greek and broader European literary receptions of Plato's theory of eros. Special emphasis is placed on the rediscovery of "Hellenic love" in British aestheticism and Greek modernism, especially in C. P. Cavafy.

title: History and Literature: Seminar
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the interaction of literary and historiographical discursive modes in Greek tradition (12th c. to modernity). Special emphasis will be placed on the genre of historical novel.

title: History and Literature: Seminar
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the interaction of literary and historiographical discursive modes in Greek tradition (12th c. to modernity). Special emphasis will be placed on the genre of historical novel.

title: Greek Modernism
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the theory and practice of Greek modernism and its response to European literary context, focusing on ``The Generation of the '30s'' and the surrealists. Topics include: tradition and modernism, nostalgia and memory, poetics and desire. All texts available in English.

title: Greek Modernism
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the theory and practice of Greek modernism and its response to European literary context, focusing on ``The Generation of the '30s'' and the surrealists. Topics include: tradition and modernism, nostalgia and memory, poetics and desire. All texts available in English.

title: Greek Modernism
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the theory and practice of Greek modernism and its response to European literary context, focusing on ``The Generation of the '30s'' and the surrealists. Topics include: tradition and modernism, nostalgia and memory, poetics and desire. All texts available in English.

title: Greek Modernism
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Explores the theory and practice of Greek modernism and its response to European literary context, focusing on "The Generation of the '30s" and the surrealists. Topics include: tradition and modernism, nostalgia and memory, poetics and desire.

title: The History and Development of the Greek Language: From the Hellenistic koine to Medieval Greek
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Translation and linguistic analysis of diverse select texts in order to show the emergence of postclassical forms of the Greek language. Readings include extracts from the New Testament; papyrus letters; early saints' lives; military and ceremonial treatises; chronicles and charters; vernacular verse and verse romances. Some prior knowledge of Greek.

title: The History and Development of the Greek Language: From the Hellenistic koine to Medieval Greek
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Translation and linguistic analysis of diverse selected texts in order to show the emergence of postclassical forms of the Greek language. Readings include extracts from the New Testament; papyrus letters; hymns of Romanos the Melodist; military and ceremonial treatises; satire and parody; verse romances and songs. Special emphasis on the 6th and 12th centuries. Some prior knowledge of Greek.

title: The History and Development of the Greek Language: From the Hellenistic koine to Medieval Greek
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Translation and linguistic analysis of diverse selected texts in order to show the emergence of postclassical forms of the Greek language. Readings include extracts from the New Testament; papyrus letters; hymns of Romanos the Melodist; military and ceremonial treatises; satire and parody; verse romances and songs. Special emphasis on the 6th and 12th centuries. Some prior knowledge of Greek.

title: The History and Development of the Greek Language: From Medieval to Modern Greek
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Translation and linguistic analysis of diverse selected texts to show the transition from medieval to modern Greek, with attention to dialect differentiation, diglossy, and the attempt to create a national language. Readings from Cypriot and Cretan dialect literature and documents of the 15th$17th centuries; language debates from Korais to Psycharis; modern poetry and prose; contemporary media debates. Open to graduates and undergraduates in the Classics, Modern Greek, Comparative Literature, and Anthropology. Additional tutorial hours for graduates. Some prior knowledge of modern Greek.

title: The History and Development of the Greek Language: From Medieval to Modern Greek
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Translation and linguistic analysis of diverse select texts in order to show the transition from medieval to modern Greek, with attention to dialect differentiation, diglossy, and the attempt to create a national language. Readings from Cypriot and Cretan dialect poetry and documents; Korais, Psicharis, and Dragoumis; modern poetry and prose; contemporary media debates. Some prior knowledge of modern Greek.

title: The History and Development of the Greek Language: From Medieval to Modern Greek
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Translation and linguistic analysis of diverse selected texts to show the transition from medieval to modern Greek, with attention to dialect differentiation, diglossy, and the attempt to create a national language. title: The History and Development of the Greek Language: From Medieval to Modern Greek
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Translation and linguistic analysis of diverse select texts in order to show the transition from medieval to modern Greek, with attention to dialect differentiation, diglossy, and the attempt to create a national language. Readings from Cypriot and Cretan dialect poetry and documents; Korais, Psicharis, and Dragoumis; modern poetry and prose; contemporary media debates. Some prior knowledge of modern Greek.

title: The History and Development of the Greek Language: From the Hellenstic Koine to Medieval Greek
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Translation and linguistic analysis of diverse selected texts to show the emergence of post-classical forms of the Greek language. Readings include extracts from the New Testament; papyrus letters; hymns of Romanos the Melodist; military and ceremonial treatises; satire and parody; verse romances; popular songs and acclamations. Open to graduates and undergraduates in the Classics, Modern Greek, Comparative Literature, and Anthropology. Additional tutorial hours for graduates. Some prior knowledge of modern Greek.

title: The History and Development of the Greek Language: From Medieval to Modern Greek
subject: MODGRK

title: Theodore Prodromos: Four Begging Poems, or "Ptocho-Prodromika"
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: A close reading of twelfth century satirical verse, with attention to manuscript tradition and to social and cultural context. Open to undergraduates with 200-level Greek.

title: Theodore Prodromos: Four Begging Poems, or "Ptocho-Prodromika"
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: A close reading of twelfth century satirical verse, with attention to manuscript tradition and to social and cultural context. Open to undergraduates with 200-level Greek.

subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: For students with no knowledge of modern Greek. Basic oral expression, listening comprehension, grammar, reading, and writing. Language instruction is supplemented by reading of simple literary passages and other texts.

title: Grammar and Reading for Heritage Speakers
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: This course is intended for heritage speakers to help them acquire the foundation in grammar and syntax necessary to enable them to take the second half of Modern Greek B or a 100-level course in the spring. By combining comprehensive grammar review with practice in reading, and presenting material related to the culture of modern Greece and the Greek Diaspora, students advance their linguistic skills while at the same time they are introduced to the history of the Greek Diaspora.

title: Grammar and Reading for Heritage Speakers
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: This course is intended for heritage speakers (i.e. those who have learned some Greek at home during childhood) to help them acquire the foundations in morphology and syntax necessary to enable them to take the second half of Intermediate Modern Greek (MODGRK Bb) or the Introduction to Modern Greek Literature (MODGRK 100) in the spring. By combining a fast-paced and comprehensive grammar review with extensive practice in reading students advance their linguistic skills while at the same time they are introduced to Modern Greek literature and culture.

title: Intermediate Modern Greek: Language and Civilization
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: For students with an elementary knowledge of modern Greek (equivalent to that acquired in Modern Greek A). Aims at further development of skills in speaking, comprehension, reading, and writing. Selected readings in prose (literary and journalistic), poetry, folksongs, modern music, and theatre serve as an introduction to aspects of modern Greek literature and culture. The second semester is conducted in Greek and focuses on topics selected by the instructor and the students in the first term. Grammar is reviewed in the context of readings.

title: Intermediate Modern Greek: Language and Civilization
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Aims at further development of skills in speaking, comprehension, reading, and writing. Aims at further development of skills in speaking, comprehension, reading, and writing, with an emphasis on vocabulary building. Selected readings in prose, poetry, and the theater as an introduction to aspects of modern Greek literature and civilization. Grammar is reviewed in the context of readings. Conducted largely in Greek.

title: Intermediate Modern Greek: Language and Civilization
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Aims at further development of skills in speaking, comprehension, reading, and writing. Selected readings in prose (literary and journalistic), poetry, folksongs, modern music, and theatre serve as an introduction to aspects of modern Greek literature and culture. The second term is conducted in Greek and focuses on topics selected by the instructor and the students in the first term. Grammar is reviewed in the context of readings. An elementary knowledge of modern Greek (equivalent to that of Modern Greek A).

subject: MODGRK

title: Mothers and Fathers
subject: MODGRK
courseDescriptionLong: Examines the relation of mother and father figures in modern Greek society, politics, literature, and film. Topics include ^'^'lost fathers,'' madonnas and whores, political patrons, women as mediators with the sacred, dictatorship, incest. Readings: folksongs and ballads, Chortatsis' Erophile, Solomos, Kavadias, Taktsis, Petropoulos, Karapanou, Fakinou. Viewing of Angelopoulos' O Megalekandros and Landscape in the Mist. Conducted largely in Greek.

title: Advanced Modern Greek: Supervised Readings

courseDescriptionLong: Advanced reading in topics agreed upon by instructor and students. Students must have completed Modern Greek B or equivalent and must have permission of the instructor. No Pass/Fail.
